displayed_text: Patient: Well yeah, it is. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not gonna run out. The time will just be when your body poops out and it’s not safe for us to continue. It’s just - Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: - stupid to continue. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because you’re you’re just not going to be able to be strong enough. Other than that - Patient: Yeah. But strong enough now. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: But I mean from a fact that I guess I’m looking for the future Doctor: Of course, Patient: though too and this question that -

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Cranberry extract, uh, twice a day. Patient: Uh, once a day; I dropped it back to once. Doctor: And the B12 once a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your Xgeva every month? Patient: The Xgeva, we stopped. Doctor: Enzalutamide, you’re still taking four pills a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: The only drug that you’ve got on here -- Patient: for two weeks and two weeks off. Doctor: You got your hormone shot - the lisinopril five milligrams a day?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Homemaker: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Homemaker

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: It’s being done for die- his diabetic condition. Doctor: Right. Patient: Yeah. So how do I counter that? Doctor: That’s where you have to go to a nephrologist ‘cause they’re smarter than me. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: They gotta work with the kidney and in your case it really is the kidney. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: Um and it just depends on where you want to see this person. I’m – Do you see the B______ docs? Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Yep. Are a R____ or T____?

Patient: I know it’s going to get better. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Uh, uh, yes. Doctor: So we have to watch you closely. I don’t know whether, how much, how much you remember when we talked about the pathology and that it invaded the seminal vesicle. Do you remember that discussion? Patient: Yeah. You were saying something, about something, something. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. It went into the seminal vesicle and so, uh, we’re going to have to just, just watch you closely. Right now, everything is fine and it may continue to be that way. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Well, that’s what we’re looking for. Doctor: Right. Patient: I’m going to try to eat right. Doctor: Right. Patient: And- Doctor: Any exercise?

Patient: This is experimental? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Patient: And uh so I would take the BET1 inhibitor and keep on the Xtandi? Doctor: That’s correct. Patient: And the Lupron? Doctor: So that’s an option. Okay? The other option is do we go now to the medications based on your BRCA mutation should we start you on Lynparza which is one of the medications that are basically given for BRCA mutation patients with prostate cancer. Okay. Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is --

Patient: …the the dark clouds over them. Doctor: Yes, yes. Patient: And and maybe that’s him. Doctor: That’s right. But you’re not gonna worry about him because the dark cloud is not on you. Patient: Right. Doctor: We’re just gonna move forward. Patient: Right, exactly right. Doctor: Awesome. Sounds like a plan. Uh as soon as we locate the right one you’ll be the first to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um I think M______ wanted to just say hi. Stick her head in here. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we all eyeball you and then (sound MD makes noise for effect)

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So I don’t really know where you’re at but I think I’m hearing that you may be interested in thinking about this radiation option first? Patient: Well as a Patient, you have a person that quote/unquote “has the cancer”. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: My primary objective would be to get rid of it. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: So if that’s not possible through the methods that you have, then what I need to look at uh is what can you offer us as far as a method of treatment um to kind of you know work on this targeted area – Doctor: Um hum. Patient: - you know still thinking that I mean you know it’s not to say this is the only place it’s going to develop. Doctor: Right. Patient: I mean you could target this - Doctor: Right.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yes. And then, of course, you know, we do do this, and I really want you to consider, you know, donating the extra bloods as we go throughout the year because I get to follow you for this whole time anyways. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So it’s not like you have to come back, and he’s, it’s just when you come back, when we stick you, we can get up to like ten extra tubes of blood because it’s that much we have to check. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Your immune system is really complicated. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we have to check everything. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah. So there’s no sticking or biopsies but it’s a blood draw. And you have lots to spare. So don’t say, “Oh, my, God”. Doctor: “She can take this ten and that’s it. I’m rolling out of here.” No. You have lots, and lots, and lots of blood to donate. Okay? Family Member: Oh, okay.

Family Member: You’re talking about placebo? Doctor: Yeah. So there is a two out of three chance that you will have a chance to get that medication. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: If, if I need that medication, I could though? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow.

Patient: then I had the heat flashes Doctor: Mhmm. Patient: and I still have them every now and then. Doctor: Mhmm. Oh okay so that’s… Patient: And then (pause) Doctor: Okay. No because I was looking into let me just see if we have to increase his uh… Are you driving back home on your own? Patient: No. My mom she’s… Doctor: Okay, somebody’s there right? Patient: Yes she – I just got to call – she out shopping right now. Doctor: Okay, no because I was gonna give you some Benadryl here also for your congestion. Sometimes um the… Patient: What’s it - For the sinus? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Patient: Yeah…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So there’s two, like I said, two knocks against you that may make, huh, everything that we just talked about, make it so that we’re not able to do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but then we can just, when I see you, plan what day you want to get chemotherapy started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Does that make sense? Patient: Yep. Doctor: And let me see if you’re all set for when your next hormone shot is. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that’s due the last week of, first week of, last week of April. And you’re set for that. You already have that appointment set up, add on because it will be three weeks from now about when we might get started with the chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? I refilled the ibuprofen. I sent it to your local pharmacy. Patient: Okay.

Patient: It’s okay. Family Member: It’s okay. Doctor: Alright. Fair deals. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So… Family Member: So we’re gonna go back on this? Doctor: Yeah I just have to check with M___ and make sure it’s all legit through the protocol. Um… Family Member: Okay. Doctor: …get you the, you know the pills if that’s the case and then we’re on our way. Patient: Mhmm. Okay. Good. Family Member: Sounds like a plan. Doctor: Okay. Anything else?

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So you’re going after them just because you can see it but there is no guarantee that what we can see on the CAT scan is the only place at this point in time where the cancer is at. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: So we might graph that lymph node and your PSA might drop by fifteen percent, then we’ll know in retrospect had we got that lymph node we might have actually killed all of the cells in that lymph node - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and yet your PSA might drop by fifteen or twenty-five percent. And so what we’ve learnt the hard way, so-to-speak with experience, is that although we can do that, it is technically feasible -um and there are some types of radiation that can be reimbursed by insurance companies, for example - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - um we have not seen cases where that is curative. That is also another type of therapy that delays the progression of the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So so for example, if your primary goal was to delay hormone therapy for as long as possible, like if you really wanted at all cost to avoid hormone therapy - Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the one thing that we could consider would be referring you to a radiation oncologist that specializes in the type of radiation called stereotactic radio therapy, which is a very sort of focused -

Patient: Well not really. I’m still taking it. Healthcare Professional: No he’s not. He’s still taking – Doctor: Oh you are still taking it. Healthcare Professional: He has to stop Doctor: No you have to stop it for a week anyway before the biopsy. Family Member: Why don’t we just stop it. Doctor: So go ahead and stop it for now. And we’ll restart it once we feel comfortable that there’s no bleeding and you know… Patient: Okay so I’m off the aspirin. Even the little ones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Totally off the aspirin. Healthcare Professional: Even the baby aspirin. Family Member: And that’s what B____ said.

Family Member: Kind of like we started with this one. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because the first couple of weeks I came down here… Doctor: It was more intense and then it… Family Member: In the beginning. Doctor: And then it smooths off once. Patient: Well okay so you’re talking three different options. Doctor: Yeah basically. Patient: Which one, which one I guess was your recommendation? Doctor: What I was going to propose is that we do things in parallel. Okay? I was going to sort of leave the chemotherapy as a last possible option only because you have it available at any time. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can go to it if none of these work or even after they work and then stop working after sometime.
